title: Grandma's Lemon Meringue Pie Recipe
description: This lemon meringue pie has a deliciously tart homemade lemon filling baked in a pie crust with a fluffy meringue topping for a dreamy dessert.

Photos This lemon meringue pie is so delicious and perfect for sharing! The homemade lemon curd filling is flavored with lemon juice and zest. It's tart, smooth, and pairs perfectly with the sweet and fluffy meringue topping. Original recipe (1X) yields 8 servings Lemon Filling: 1 cup white sugar 2 tablespoons all-purpose flour 3 tablespoons cornstarch ¼ teaspoon salt 1 ½ cups water 2 medium lemons, juiced and zested 2 tablespoons butter 4 egg yolks, beaten 1 (9 inch) prepared pie crust, baked Meringue: 4 egg whites ½ cup white sugar Directions Gather all ingredients and preheat the oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C). Dotdash Meredith Food Studios To make the lemon filling: Whisk 1 cup sugar, flour, cornstarch, and salt together in a medium saucepan; stir in water, lemon juice, and lemon zest. Cook over medium-high heat, stirring frequently, until mixture comes to a boil. Stir in butter. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Place egg yolks in a small bowl and gradually whisk in 1/2 cup of hot sugar mixture. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Whisk egg yolk mixture back into remaining sugar mixture. Bring to a boil and continue to cook while stirring constantly until thick. Remove from heat; pour filling into baked pastry crust. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios To make the meringue topping: Beat egg whites in a glass, metal, or ceramic bowl with an electric mixer until foamy. Gradually add sugar, continuing to beat until stiff peaks form. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Working quickly, spread meringue over pie filling, sealing the edges at the crust. Use the back of the spoon to create peaks on the top of the meringue if you like. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Bake pie in the preheated oven until meringue is golden brown, about 20 to 25 minutes. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Serve and enjoy! Dotdash Meredith Food Studios I Made It Print 5,726 home cooks made it! Easy to follow Family favorite 03 of 1,280 Photo by  Allrecipes Member 03/23/2025 I did add a little more zest. Í followed everything else on the recipe. Did the meringue as directed. Got it to foamy stage added the sugar slowly as the egg whites were betting on high and waited a couple minutes and beautiful meringue. 04 of 1,280 Photo by  Tammy Mccollum 03/21/2025 Easy to follow Great flavors A keeper! Went by the recipe. Turned out great! Very good taste! 05 of 1,280 Photo by  PoliteBacon6345 02/06/2025 Great flavors Worth the effort A keeper! I did as one reviewer shared: bake pie crust before adding filling, double the ingredients ( especially for a 10 inch pie, & use milk rather than water & of course fresh squeezed and zested lemons!! It came out perfect - best pie I’ve ever made. 06 of 1,280 Photo by  deanne 02/01/2025 Worth the effort A keeper! First time since ages I’ve made lemon meringue pie. Still in the oven looking wonderful! This was served to a group of friends and it went over well! Delicious… Only change I would make is add one more lemon. I used 1/3 cup of Meyer lemon juice and another lemon would just increase the lemon flavor. 07 of 1,280 Photo by  Larry Glavich 02/01/2025 A keeper! Easy to follow My first time making a meringue anything. The recipe was easy to follow, and by doing all your prep work first and have everything ready, very quick to do. The flavor is great. The meringue did take me some time bearing it at medium to medium-high speed, also adding a touch of cornstarch and creme of tartar. But I did advertise the 'peaky' consistency I wanted. Definitely a go-to recipe for when I make this again and again. 08 of 1,280 Photo by  NewPork9819 12/26/2024 This was a fairly easy recipe to use. I used 6 table spoons of lemon juice as I didn't have fresh lemons to squeeze. I also added 1/2 tsp of Cream of Tartar to the meringue so it doesn't weep. 09 of 1,280 Photo by  Nancy 12/26/2024 A keeper! No runs, No drips, No errors . . .I used 1/2 cup fresh squeezed Meyer lemon juice and all of the zest from the involved very fresh and juicy lemons. My lemon pies had become a disappointment to me lately by being watery. Maybe the combo of cornstarch and flour is the answer to tame the particular acidity I was blaming for the watery fluid that made the crusts soggy and wet.
